There currently is no requirement that the Virginia Department of Corrections provide data about who and how many people it is holding in solitary confinement. That needs to change.

Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

The practice of solitary confinement is inhumane, and yet little accurate information exists about what the Virginia Department of Corrections (VDOC) is doing in our state prisons.

We know that placing someone in a small cell, alone, with little to no normal stimuli, human interaction, or out-of-cell time for 22-24 hours a day causes mental and physical deterioration. It exacerbates and even causes mental illness. While an international human rights standard says no one should be held in solitary for more than 15 consecutive days, we know that some people have been caged in solitary in Virginia prisons for years.

What we don’t know definitively is how many people, why they were placed there, or whether they may have mental illness or are members of other vulnerable groups that should never be placed in solitary confinement. The reason we don’t know is that the VDOC doesn’t even have to record those numbers.

There are currently three bills in the Virginia legislature — one in the House of Delegates and two in the Senate — that would require the VDOC to collect this important information and report it to the governor and legislature once a year.

Take action now and ask your elected representatives to support this important effort to find out who and how many people are suffering in these conditions in our state prisons.

Take Action

Thanks as always for your invaluable support.

Claire G. Gastanaga
Executive Director, ACLU of Virginia
